key_insight: A spike-driven video transformer fuses event-like (sparse) spiking dynamics with transformer-style spatio-temporal attention to deliver accurate surgical scene segmentation while greatly reducing compute and power, making real-time operation on resource-constrained platforms feasible.
problem_solved: Current high‑accuracy segmentation models (especially large video transformers) are too compute- and power-hungry for real-time intra‑operative use on edge/embedded surgical systems; this work targets low-latency, energy-efficient segmentation for surgical scenes.
method: Integrate spiking (event-driven) neural elements with a video transformer backbone to exploit temporal sparsity and reduce redundant computations.
Use spatio-temporal attention tailored for video frames plus spike-based updates to maintain segmentation accuracy with lower activation overhead.
Design choices focused on low latency and energy efficiency (e.g., sparse updates, hardware-friendly operations) to enable real-time potential on resource-constrained devices.
impact: Enables deployment of high-quality surgical scene segmentation on edge and embedded OR systems, reducing inference energy and latency while preserving accuracy—important for safety-critical, time-sensitive intra‑operative assistance. Practitioners get a path toward real‑time, low-power video segmentation models.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram showing standard video transformer vs. spike-driven video transformer (highlight sparse, event-driven paths).
Before/after surgical frame with segmentation overlay to show qualitative results.
Bar chart comparing latency and energy (or FLOPs) between dense transformer, lightweight baselines, and the spike-driven model.
Timeline or animation storyboard illustrating sparse spike events across frames vs. dense frame-by-frame processing.
paper_title: Surgical Scene Segmentation using a Spike-Driven Video Transformer with Real-Time Potential
paper_authors: Shihao Zou, Jingjing Li, Wei Ji, Jincai Huang, Kai Wang
